instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC: What is SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC? SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC is a voltage that is created if SMC_BC_ACOK & PP3V42_G3H are both present that powers the chipset for the onewire circuit that allows the SMC to talk to the charger on the SYS_ONEWIRE line. This is necessary for the magsafe charger to have a light on it. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message:
I've got an issue with this logic board and the lack of a boardview makes it harder to diagnose. The ISL chip (<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>) gets warm I've got good readings at both <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. Some concerns I have is I have no readings for <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC</SIGNAL> and my reading for <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> for both pin 1/2 is showing around 1.8V. Also my <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> voltage is showing at 0.7V. My U700 only gives voltage at <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> and <CHIP>U7001</CHIP> at pin 1/2 and pin 5 (<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>).

I've looked at every possible components linked to these for shorts but to no avail. I was hoping if someone can shine some light to my situation or give me some general guidance in how to diagnose macbooks.

Also I am using the 85W charger for this board so my readings should be accurate.

Thank you,
Sam

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> should be 3.4V. Check resistance to GND on this line and check the pull up <RESISTOR>R5087</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message:
Yeah that's what I thought.
Resistance at pin 1 and 2 shows 429 (in diode mode). Couldn't find <RESISTOR>R5087</RESISTOR> but found <RESISTOR>R5187</RESISTOR> which gives 680 (in diode mode)

If I were to measure it in an actual setting then which one? (200, 2K, 20K, 200K etc)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message:
Usually you can start at 200 and move up until it starts showing you a result.

In this case <RESISTOR>R5187</RESISTOR> is supposed to be around 470KOhm, so you should select 2M.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message: Need resistance to GND and not diode mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message:
For <RESISTOR>R5187</RESISTOR> i get 0.47 - 0.478 MOhms.

(I can't find anything either in the schematics or boardview on <RESISTOR>R5087</RESISTOR>.)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message: Still waiting for <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> resistance to GND....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message:
Been trying to get an actual reading at <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> at both pins but they seem gradually go up and surpass 20MOhms.

I'm fairly new to the repairs so I'm not too sure whether this information is adequate.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message: At this point it could be any component on the ACOK line that pulls it down. I would go for the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> first and pray because else it is pretty sure the SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message:
Ordered the ISL chip (should come for Thursday), until then I'll keep at it and update the page once I've got some result. 
Thanks for the help so far dukefawks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message: You might want to order a bunch of them at once since you will probably be replacing this more often on various devices, its one of the must haves

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message:
Hey smiba, thanks will do! This is my 4th macbook repair so still getting to grips with it.
I was wondering is there any way i can test that the chip is faulty? maybe by taking it out and checking for specific pins that come out short to ground?

Thank you for your help aswell smiba!

regards.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message: /Technically/ you could solder it onto a circuit board using the same chip just to test it, but why bother? The chip is like $4, its not worth your time, just use a new one! :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message:
No Title

What can people make out of this. The boardview I have is for the 2014 model (since the 2015 version isn't easily available).
In comparing the two there is only two resistors below the SMC (however I don't think the third one actually connects to anything so that should be okay). Secondly it seems that the track is somewhat damaged and lastly there is a missing capacitor underneath it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message:
That SMC looks reflowed without having the edge bonding removed... 
You can see if the track is damaged by using diode mode. Voltage drop should be 0

Also this area looks really awful

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message:
SMC was reflowed with edge bonding in place, so that probably needs to be pulled and reballed now. 
That corroded area in smiba's picture is for Airport stuff so not important right now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message:
Thank you everyone for your help.
Unfortunately the new chip didn't bring the board to life, doing the exact same thing as before. 
Customer decided to go for the more expensive option of going to apple for a replacement macbook.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro 2015 - No green light on charger
threads.message: There are no "new" chips, you have to take one from an identical donor board.
